description: From Middle English quyksande, from Old English cwecesand (“quicksand”), equivalent to quick (“living”) +‎ sand. Cognate with Swedish kvicksand (“quicksand”), Icelandic kviksandur, kviksyndi (“quicksand”). More at quick, sand.

entries.meaning: Wet sand that appears firm but in which things readily sink, often found near rivers or coasts.
examples: My feet were firmly lodged in the quicksand, and the more I struggled the more I sank into it.

entries.meaning: Anything that pulls one down or buries one metaphorically
